variant.question: In straight and level flight at a constant IAS and ignoring compressibility effects, changing which of the following would change the amount of induced drag?

options.text: Aircraft weight
Tailwind
Headwind
Altitude

variant.question: In which of the flight conditions listed below is the thrust required (Tr) equal to the drag (D)?

options.text: In level flight with constant IAS.
In a descent with constant TAS.
In accelerated level flight.
In a climb with constant IAS.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Which of the following graphs illustrate the movement of the total drag curve when the undercarriage is extended?

options.text: Figure 4
Figure 2
Figure 1
Figure 3

variant.question: What happens to thrust required and drag if you fly below V~MD~?

options.text: Thrust required increases and drag increases.
Thrust required increases and drag decreases.
Thrust required decreases and drag increases.
Thrust required decreases and drag decreases.

variant.question:
Assume glide with zero thrust and zero wind
 Is there any difference between the vertical speed versus forward speed curves for two identical aeroplanes having different masses?

options.text: Yes, the difference is that for a given angle of attack both the vertical and forward speeds of the heavier aeroplane will be larger.
Yes, the difference is that the lighter aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.
Yes, the difference is that the heavier aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.
No difference.

variant.question: On the Power versus TAS graph for level flight, the point at which a tangent from the origin touches the power required curve:

options.text: is the point where the Lift to Drag ratio is a maximum.
is the maximum drag speed.
is the point where the Lift to Drag ratio is a minimum.
is the point where Drag coefficient is a minimum.

variant.question: When is the latest a pilot can take the first action to abort

options.text: At V1
When in a stable steady climb
2 Seconds Before V1
VR

variant.question: In level flight at a given speed, what happens to the drag if aeroplane mass is increased?

options.text: It increases.
It stays constant.
It decreases.
It is NOT affected.

variant.question: In straight and level flight at constant indicated airspeed, a reduction in pressure altitude:

options.text: reduces the power required.
increases the power required.
does not affect the power required.
increases or reduces the power required depending on the airspeed.

variant.question: Considering TAS for maximum range and maximum endurance, other factors remaining constant:

options.text: both will increase with increasing altitude.
TAS for maximum range will increase with increased altitude while TAS for maximum endurance will decrease with increased altitude.
both will stay constant regardless of altitude.
both will decrease with increasing altitude.

variant.question:
The pilots of a jet aircraft wish to reach the destination with minimum use of fuel
They should fly at

options.text: max Range Cruise Speed.
best L/D Speed.
minimum Power Speed.
long Range Cruise Speed.

variant.question: When does THRUST = DRAG?

options.text: Flying level at a constant IAS.
All of the above.
Climbing at a constant IAS.
Descending at a constant IAS.

variant.question: When flying the Back side of Thrust curve means...

options.text: a lower airspeed requires more thrust.
a lower airspeed requires less thrust because drag is decreased.
a thrust reduction results in an acceleration of the aeroplane.
the thrust required is independent of the airspeed.

variant.question: With all engines out, a pilot wants to fly for maximum time. - Therefore he has to fly the speed corresponding to:

options.text: the minimum power required.
the critical Mach number.
the minimum angle of descent.
the maximum lift.

variant.question: In which of the flight conditions listed below is the thrust equal to the drag?

options.text: In unaccelerated level flight
In a descent with constant TAS
In a climb with constant IAS
In accelerated level flight

variant.question: Regarding unaccelerated horizontal flight, Minimum Drag is:

options.text: proportional to aeroplane mass.
independent of the aeroplane mass.
a function of the density altitude.
a function of the pressure altitude.

variant.question: If the thrust available exceeds the thrust required for level flight:

options.text: the aeroplane accelerates if the altitude is maintained.
the aeroplane decelerates if the altitude is maintained.
the aeroplane descends if the airspeed is maintained.
the aeroplane decelerates if it is in the region of reversed command.

variant.question: With regard to an unaccelerated horizontal flight, which of the following statements concerning Minimum Drag is correct?

options.text: it is proportional to the aircraft mass.
it is independant of the aircraft mass.
it is a function of the pressure altitude.
it is a function of the density altitude.

variant.question: What happens when flying at the backside of the power curve?

options.text: The speed is unstable.
The elevator must be pulled to lower the nose.
The aeroplane will not stall.
The altitude cannot be maintained.

variant.question: For a propeller aeroplane with a naturally aspirated engine (not turbocharged), how does the maximum TAS in level flight vary with increasing altitude? The maximum achievable TAS will...

options.text: decrease steadily.
increases linearly with a headwind component
increase linearly with a tailwind component
increase steadily.

variant.question:
**Complete the following sentence:**
The maximum achievable straight and level flight IAS of a piston- engined aeroplane___.

options.text: Decrease with altitude.
Increase until transition altitude and remains constant thereafter.
Decrease until transition altitude and remains constant thereafter.
Increase with altitude.

variant.question: Which option is a correct statement about power settings for a single-engined piston aeroplane with regard to range and endurance?

options.text: The power setting for Maximum Range is higher than that for Maximum Endurance.
From a given power setting, increasing the power decreases the endurance.
From a given power setting, increasing the power increases the range.
The Maximum Range is achieved with the power setting for Maximum Endurance.

variant.question: For a piston engine propeller aircraft, how is maximum achievable IAS in straight and level flight affected by altitude?

options.text: It decreases steadily with altitude.
It increases steadily with altitude.
It increases up to the transition altitude and decreases thereafter.
It is approximately the same at all altitudes.

variant.question: What speed can be found on both intersections of the thrust required curve with the thrust available curve?

options.text: V~S~ and V~MAX~
V~X ~and V~MAX~
V~Y~ and V~S~
V~X~ and V~Y~

variant.question: What speed can be found on both intersections of the thrust required curve with the thrust available curve?

options.text: VS and VMAX
VX and VMAX
VY and VS
VX and VY

variant.question: What speed can be found on both intersections of the thrust required curve with the thrust available curve?

options.text: VS and VMAX
VY and VS
VX and VY C
VX and VMAX

variant.question: In straight horizontal steady flight, at speeds below that for minimum drag:

options.text: a lower speed requires a higher thrust.
a higher speed, but still below that for minimum drag requires a higher thrust.
the aeroplane can be controlled only in level flight.
the aeroplane cannot be controlled manually.

variant.question: In straight horizontal steady flight, at speeds below that for minimum drag:

options.text: a lower speed requires a higher thrust.
the aeroplane can be controlled only in level flight.
a higher speed, but still below that for minimum drag, requires a higher thrust.
the aeroplane cannot be controlled manually.

variant.question: For climb performance calculations, which altitude is used as a reference to calculate the average TAS through the climb? The altitude that is

options.text: two thirds of the climb between take-off and cruise altitudes.
one third of the climb between take-off and cruise altitudes.
the final cruising altitude.
half of the climb between take-off and cruise altitudes.

variant.question: How does the power required curve move with an increase in altitude when plotted on the chart against TAS?

options.text: Up and to the right.
Straight across to the right.
Straight down.
Straight up.

variant.question: What speed is the minimum point on the thrust required vs airspeed graph and where is it used for jets?

options.text: Best endurance, used to maximise airborne time
Best EAS/Drag ratio, used to minimise fuel flow
Best endurance, used to airborne maximise range (NAM)
Best range, used to maximise aircraft range

variant.question: Refer to a turbojet aeroplane which is maintianing a constant IAS and pressure altitude. Assumption: An ISA deviation of ±1 °C results in a change in fuel flow of ±0.2 %. What is the change in the specific fuel consumption if the outside air temperature is 10 °C warmer than ISA?

options.text: The SFC increases by 2 %.
The SFC decreases by 2 %.
The SFC increases by 20 %.
The SFC decreases by 20 %.

variant.question: Upon first contact with their destination aerodrome, the crew of a jet aeroplane is informed to expect a few holds due to high traffic. What can the crew do to increase their aircraft's maximum endurance?

options.text: Cruise with V~MD~ in order to minimise fuel used per unit of time.
Request a continuous descent in order to reduce the thrust setting.
Climb to the optimum altitude in order to increase specific range.
Cruise with V~max range~ in order to increase the fuel mileage.

variant.question: Which statement is correct for a descent without engine thrust at maximum lift to drag ratio speed?

options.text: A tailwind component increases the ground distance.
A tailwind component increases fuel consumtion and time to descent.
A headwind component increases the ground distance.
A tailwind component decreases the time in the descent.

variant.question: Which statement is correct for a descent without engine thrust at maximum lift to drag ratio speed?

options.text: A tailwind component increases the ground distance.
A tailwind component decreases the ground distance.
A tailwind component increases fuel and time to descent.
A headwind component increases the ground distance.

variant.question: Which statement is correct for a descent without engine thrust at maximum lift to drag ratio speed?

options.text: The higher the gross mass the greater is the speed for descent.
The mass of an aeroplane does not have any effect on the speed for descent.
The higher the average temperature (OAT) the lower is the speed for descent.
The higher the gross mass the lower is the speed for descent.

variant.question: From 500 ft above the destination aerodrome to FL50, a multi-engined piston (MEP) aeroplane performs a steady climb, maintaining a constant speed of 120 kt IAS. During this climb, the ‘’Power Required vs. TAS’’ curve will move (1) _____ and the ‘’Power Available vs. TAS’’ curve will move (2) _____.

options.text: (1) up and right; (2) down and right
(1) down and right; (2) up and right
(1) down and left; (2) up and left
(1) up and left; (2) down and left

variant.question: Presuming constant thrust and level flight, how would (1) induced drag and (2) TAS change with a decrease in mass?

options.text: (1) decreases, (2) increases
(1) increases, (2) decreases
(1) Remains constant, (2) decreases
(1) Remains constant, (2) increases

variant.question: Regarding a non-turbocharged propeller aircraft, how is maximum TAS affected by altitude?

options.text: It decreases steadily.
It increases initially, then decreases.
It increases steadily .
It increases linearly with a headwind component.

variant.question: Other factors remaining constant, how does increasing altitude affect V~X~ and V~Y~ in terms of TAS?

options.text: Both will increase.
Both remain constant.
VY remains constant and VX increases.
VY remains constant and VX decreases.

variant.question: For a propeller aeroplane with an un-supercharged engine, how does the maximum achievable TAS in level flight vary with increasing altitude? The Maximum achievable TAS...

options.text: decreases.
does not change
increases
increases initially and then decreases.

variant.question: How does drag change with weight?

options.text: Drag increases with increasing weight
Drag decreases with increasing weight
Drag is not related to aircraft weight
Drag increases and then decreases after reaching critical mass

variant.question: Where can the maximum speed in straight and level flight be found?

options.text: Where the maximum thrust equals to the total drag
Where the thrust does not increase further with increasing speed
Where the thrust is equal to the maximum drag
Where the thrust is equal to the minimum drag

variant.question: What will be achieved by flying the speed for maximum endurance in cruise?

options.text: Maximum time in the air
Maximum payload capability
Minimising of flight crew numbers
Maximum flight distance

variant.question: In straight and level flight the lift is opposed by the

options.text: weight.
drag and weight.
thrust.
drag.

variant.question: (Refer to the annex or CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.3) - Given: - O.A.T.: ISA + 15° C - Pressure Altitude: 0 ft - Aeroplane Mass: 3400 lb - Flaps: up - Speed: 100 KIAS - With regard to the climb performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the rate of climb.

options.text: 1290 ft/min
1370 ft/min
1150 ft/min
1210 ft/min

variant.question: A pilot is cruising at FL 280. 10 min before TOD they get a clearance to climb to optimum altitude FL 320. Why wouldn’t the pilot accept the clearance?

options.text: A climb would require more fuel than a short cruise at FL 280 before TOD.
The optimum altitude will decrease in the following 10 minutes and be closer to FL 280.
The arrival is more complicated to perform from FL 320 than FL 280.
Insufficient fuel as the aircraft is near its destination.

variant.question: The load factor in a turn in level flight with constant TAS depends on...

options.text: the bank angle only.
the radius of the turn and the weight of the aeroplane.
the radius of the turn and the bank angle.
the true airspeed and the bank angle.

variant.question: A pilot is flying to a destination close to the aeroplane maximum range, flying at maximum range cruise speed, with NO significant forecast winds. However, during the flight the pilot experienced a headwind. To achieve maximum range over the ground, the pilot should ...

options.text: Increase the airspeed compared to the speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.
Continue to fly at an airspeed equal to speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.
Decrease the airspeed compared to the speed for maximum cruise with NO wind.
Fly at an airspeed equal to the maximum endurance speed.

variant.question: A higher pressure altitude at ISA temperature...

options.text: decreases the field length limited take-off mass.
decreases the take-off distance.
increases the climb limited take-off mass.
has no influence on the allowed take-off mass.
